 McCain has been all over the place when it comes to equal rights for gay people. He opposed the federal amendment to restrict marriage in the constitution and exclude gay people, but he supported the proposed amendment in Arizona to exclude gay people from marriage. He has not had anything resembling a consistent position on this. 
 
 I do not think that the Republicans have given up on the election. Indeed, I am not certain that American voters will choose either a woman or a black man for President. They usually won't say this out loud, of course. But I can foresee McCain being elected. I think racism and sexism are still very strong in our country, even though people are less likely to speak how they really feel out loud. But people vote in private. We may end up with President McCain. 
 
 I also think that McCain's rise demonstrates the limit of the power of the Christian right. Bush was able to bring together the religious right, with which he identified, and the business leadership of the Republican Party, with which he also identified. He embodied this unlikely coalition in himself. Now the coalition has split apart. This is a great hope, I think, for those of us who want to see a Democrat in the White House. McCain, the mostly Republican nominee now, is in no way of the religious right, and many on the religious right will not support him. He also makes the leaders of the Republican Party uncomfortable, but they will support him. The coalition that brought the Republicans to power has come apart, and Democrats can capitalize on this. But will most voters elect a woman or a black man? I hope so. We will see.
 
 Whatever happens, even if McCain gets elected in November, our government won't be as horrible for gay people and for the country as a whole as it was under Bush. We will most likely have a Democratic Congress, whoever is elected President. And for all his flip-flopping on gay rights, McCain has never been a darling of the Christian right, and they can't pressure him into pushing anti-gay laws on the nation. I think McCain prefers simply to avoid the issue of gay people as much as possible. (Bush actually expressed the same thoughts; he had to be pressured by the religious right to come out in favor of the anti-marriage amendment. But he was able to be pressured, because the Christian right helped elect Bush. McCain would not be in the same position.)

 I think the main difference is that he's not in the pocket of the religious right. This is a good change for the Republican party, and I think people (in the party) have known for some time that the influence of the RR would eventually wane, in part because nothing like that lasts forever. It's been waning for some time now. However, that doesn't necessarily translate to wins on the part of Democrats. The Republican party has operated outside the influence of the RR before, and they can do it again if need be. Reagan sort of began that reliance on the RR, but for him it was still nominal as compared to today, and McCain would probably be a return to that sort of level of reliance. If you reject the idea that RR conservatism is true conservatism (in the Goldwater bent), one could argue he's MORE conservative than Bush, depending on the way you view conservatism. Bush and McCain embody different types of conservatism, IMO. And let's face it, McCain has certainly demonstrated a willingness to work with people across the aisle.
 
 I do agree that there could very well be people out there who are uncomfortable with a woman as president. I think it could be more so that way than with a black president. But I fear that if either or both of them lose in the end, then the automatic excuse given by their supporters will be because of prejudice, and that will not be giving the American people enough credit if that happens.
 
 I think the greater danger for democrats, more so than racism or misoginism, is simply that McCain could turn out to be a candidate that is more appealing in terms of issues like national security (which Dems ALWAYS seem to underestimate as a public concern, as evidenced yet again in the DNC debate tonight). I am pretty surprised at how little the DNC candidates are discussing it, given how much Democrats have taken a beating over it in recent years. They seem to be hedging their bet on a recession (which may indeed happen)--trying to shift the economy as a pet issue. I think the best chance they have is to shore up their weakness of national security.
